item.title: Odds of Metabolic Disease Lower With Fast Subjective Walking Speed in Patients With Obesity - HealthDay
item.description:
Odds of Metabolic Disease Lower With Fast Subjective Walking Speed in Patients With Obesity

Date: Dec. 30, 2024 | Source: HealthDay News

This study indicates that a faster subjective walking speed correlates with a reduced risk of metabolic diseases in individuals with obesity.

  • Study published in Scientific Reports on Nov. 15.
  • Examined 8,578 individuals with a BMI ≥25.0 kg/m2.
  • Found a risk ratio of 0.70 for diabetes mellitus in individuals with obesity and fast walking speed.
  • Different risk ratios highlighted for various metabolic diseases based on waist circumference and BMI.
"This study revealed that even in those with obesity, who have a higher risk of metabolic diseases, a fast subjective walking speed was associated with lower odds of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and dyslipidemia."

The findings suggest that encouraging faster walking could play a significant role in reducing the prevalence of metabolic diseases among obese individuals.

item.title: Microplastics found in multiple human organ tissues correlated with lesions - Phys.org
item.description:
Microplastics Found in Multiple Human Organ Tissues Correlated with Lesions

Publication Date: 30 December 2024 | Source: Science X Network

Research indicates concerning correlations between microplastics in human tissues and various health conditions, highlighting the widespread impact of plastic pollution.

  • Study led by Zhejiang Agriculture and Forestry University performed a metadata investigation into microplastics in humans.
  • Established links between microplastics and health conditions, noting concentrations were higher in damaged tissues.
  • Microplastics present in diverse human organs, including skin, lungs, and reproductive systems.
  • Calls for reliable methods to assess risks and mitigation measures for microplastic exposure.
"Measured levels of microplastics tended to be higher in tissues with lesions than in non-lesioned tissues, suggesting a potential link between MNP buildup and local pathology."

Further research is needed to explore the causal relationships between microplastic accumulation and health impacts.

item.title: Every cigarette takes 17 minutes off life expectancy in men, 22 in women: Study - The Times of India
item.description:
Every cigarette takes 17 minutes off life expectancy in men, 22 in women: Study

Publication Date: 2023-10-02 Source: Study Findings

This study highlights the significant impact of smoking on life expectancy, revealing that each cigarette reduces life expectancy by an average of 17 minutes for men and 22 minutes for women.

  • The average life lost due to each cigarette is alarming, emphasizing the health risks associated with smoking.
  • The gender disparity in life expectancy reduction indicates different health impacts based on sex.
  • The study calls for increased public health awareness and smoking cessation programs.
“Every cigarette smoked is a step towards a shorter life.”

In conclusion, this study serves as a stark reminder of the dangers of smoking and the need for health policies aimed at reducing tobacco consumption.

item.title: Milestone: COVID-19 five years ago - World Health Organization
item.description:
Milestone: COVID-19 five years ago

Publication Date: 31 December 2024 Source: WHO Media Team

Five years ago on 31 December 2019, WHO’s Country Office in China picked up a media statement by the Wuhan Municipal Health Commission about 'viral pneumonia' cases in Wuhan, which led to the emergence of COVID-19 and its profound impact on global lives.

  • WHO activated emergency systems on 1 January 2020 and informed the world on 4 January.
  • The first comprehensive guidance was published by WHO between 9-12 January 2020.
  • On 13 January, WHO collaborated with partners to develop the first SARS-CoV-2 laboratory test.
  • As we take this milestone moment, we honor those who suffered and died, and express gratitude to healthcare workers.
  • WHO continues to urge China to share data on COVID-19's origins, vital for future preparedness.
“Is the world better prepared for the next pandemic than we were for COVID-19?” - Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus

As we reflect on the past five years, we emphasize the lessons learned to build a healthier future and ensure better preparedness for potential pandemics.

item.title: Mediterranean To DASH Diet: Top 7 Healthy Diets You Must Try In 2025 - Times Now
item.description:
Mediterranean To DASH Diet: Top 7 Healthy Diets You Must Try In 2025

Publication Date: 2025   |   Source: Times Now

This article presents seven healthy diets that are popular and effective for 2025, providing insights into their benefits and expert recommendations.

  • Mediterranean Diet: Focuses on fresh produce, whole grains, and healthy fats. Supports heart health.
  • Plant-Based Diet: Emphasizes vegetables and legumes. Linked to reduced risk of type 2 diabetes.
  • Flexitarian Diet: A flexible mix of plant-based and occasional animal products. Sustainable and balanced.
  • DASH Diet: Reduces high blood pressure through potassium-rich foods. Supported by research for heart health.
  • Nordic Diet: Rich in whole grains and fatty fish. Promotes heart health and reduces inflammation.
  • Intermittent Fasting (IF): Focuses on meal timing. Aids in weight management and metabolic health.
  • Probiotic-Rich Diet: Includes foods like yogurt and kimchi. Supports gut health and immunity.

To get started, choose a diet that fits your lifestyle, consult with a nutrition professional, make gradual changes, and stay consistent.

item.title: Influenza Vaccine Effective Against Severe Illness in Children - Clinical Advisor
item.description:
Influenza Vaccine Effective Against Severe Illness in Children

Date: Published on JAMA Network Open

Source: HealthDay News

The influenza vaccine is reported to be effective in preventing severe illness among children based on a study conducted by the CDC. The research involved over 15,000 children and showed that vaccination significantly helps reduce hospital visits due to influenza.

  • The study analyzed data from 8 medical centers across different states.
  • Out of 15,728 children, 2710 tested positive for influenza.
  • Vaccination was associated with a 55.7% effectiveness in preventing emergency department visits or hospitalizations.
  • The effectiveness was consistent across different illness severity levels.
  • Improving vaccine uptake is emphasized as crucial for reducing influenza complications.
“Vaccination is one of the most effective ways to protect children against influenza and its complications, including severe illness and hospitalization.”

This study underscores the importance of influenza vaccination to protect children and optimize healthcare resources during peak respiratory virus seasons.

item.title: How can we manage stress from bossy bosses and deadlines? | Health Wealth, Ep 76 - India Today Podcast
item.description:
How can we manage stress from bossy bosses and deadlines? | Health Wealth, Ep 76

Publication Date: N/A Source: Health Wealth

This episode discusses the rise of work-related stress in the 21st century, exploring whether we are solving these stressors or simply becoming more obsessed with them. Integrative lifestyle medicine expert Luke Coutinho shares actionable solutions to improve our ability to handle workplace challenges.

  • Work-related stress may have increased due to modern demands.
  • Luke Coutinho's six pillars for wellness can mitigate stress.
  • Adjustments in diet, exercise, sleep, and emotional health are crucial.
  • Work should enhance, not govern, our happiness and peace of mind.
“Ensure work remains a part of life, not the governor of your happiness and peace of mind.”

Tune in to gain insights into managing stress effectively.

item.title: Weight loss at home: Simple exercises to shed pounds and keep active this winter - The Times of India
item.description:
Weight Loss at Home: Simple Exercises to Shed Pounds and Keep Active This Winter

Publication Date: Unknown Source: Unknown

This article provides readers with effective and simple exercises they can do at home to aid in weight loss and maintain their fitness levels during the winter months.

  • Focuses on easy-to-follow home workouts.
  • Encourages physical activity to combat winter lethargy.
  • Highlights the benefits of staying active for mental and physical health.
“Staying active during the winter is crucial for both physical and mental well-being.”

The article emphasizes the importance of creating a consistent workout routine even when the weather outside is not conducive to outdoor activities.

item.title: FDA approves lenacapavir for HIV treatment; Science journal hails it as 'breakthrough of the year' - The New Indian Express
item.description:
FDA Approves Lenacapavir for HIV Treatment; Science Journal Hails it as 'Breakthrough of the Year'

Publication Date: 30 Dec 2024
Source: AP

The FDA has approved Lenacapavir, an injectable drug that protects against HIV for six months with each dose, which has been recognized by Science journal as a major breakthrough in combating the HIV/AIDS crisis.

  • Lenacapavir provides long-term protection against HIV with biannual injections.
  • Science journal labeled it 'breakthrough of the year' for its efficacy in HIV prevention.
  • Clinical trials showed 100% efficacy among African adolescent girls and 99.9% among gender-diverse populations.
  • HOPE for reducing global HIV infections relies on access and demand for the drug.
"It has the potential if we can do it right, which means going big and getting it out there." - Linda-Gail Bekker, University of Cape Town

Lenacapavir represents a significant advancement in HIV prevention, with the potential to transform public health efforts against the epidemic.

item.title: Sick kids and cold season blues: Ultimate guide for parents to prevent dehydration in children - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Boosting Kids' Immunity: A Parent's Guide to Preventing Dehydration During Illness

Date & Source: Published on HT Lifestyle

Introduction: Seasonal changes often bring fluctuating weather conditions and an increased risk of illnesses in children, which can lead to dehydration and reduced energy levels.

  1. Dehydration and its impact on immunity: Pediatric expert Dr. NL Sridhar explains that dehydration can weaken children's immunity and leave them more vulnerable to infections.
  2. How seasonal illnesses lead to dehydration: Fever, nausea, and vomiting are common in children during seasonal changes and can result in fluid, electrolyte, and energy deficits.
  3. Highlighting the role of fluid, electrolyte, and energy (FEE) deficits in supporting recovery: Dr. NL Sridhar emphasizes the importance of replenishing fluids, electrolytes, and energy to counteract the effects of dehydration.
  4. The Role of Electrolytes in Recovery: Electrolytes like sodium, potassium, and magnesium are vital for recovery during seasonal illnesses.
  5. The Importance of Timely Intervention: Early identification and management of dehydration and energy deficits can significantly improve recovery in children.
Notable Quote: "Ready-to-drink formulations with a scientifically balanced composition of electrolytes and energy are particularly beneficial as they ensure consistent quality and taste." - Dr. NL Sridhar

Conclusion: Parents should remain vigilant for signs of dehydration and consult pediatricians for appropriate care, prioritizing hydration and addressing energy needs to help children navigate seasonal transitions with resilience and good health.

Disclaimer: The information provided in this article are scientific facts only and not a substitute for any professional advice. Please consult a doctor / nutritionist for more information on managing dehydration during infections.

item.title: Female Sex Hormone Oestrogen Might Be The Reason Ladies Binge On Alcohol; Study Reveals - Free Press Journal
item.description:
Female Sex Hormone Oestrogen Might Be The Reason Ladies Binge On Alcohol; Study Reveals

Publication Date: December 30, 2024

Source: Weill Cornell Medicine

The study reveals that oestrogen regulates binge drinking in females, highlighting the increase in heavy alcohol consumption among women.

  • The research indicates that circulating oestrogen levels affect binge drinking behaviors in females.
  • Women have increased their heavy alcohol consumption rates more than men in recent years.
  • High oestrogen levels can enhance alcohol's harmful effects.
  • The findings may inform new treatments for alcohol use disorder in women.
“When a female takes her first sip from the bottle containing alcohol, those neurons go crazy.” - Dr. Kristen Pleil

Understanding the role of oestrogen in alcohol consumption may lead to significant health implications for women.

item.title: Your dog could have diabetes. Yes, you read that right - India Today
item.description:
Your Dog Could Have Diabetes: A Common Yet Often Unnoticed Condition

Published on Dec 31, 2023 - Source: India Today

Diabetes in pets, especially dogs and cats, is more common than many pet owners realize. While it's not as prevalent as in humans, it's a serious condition that requires proper management. Sadly, around 20% of pets with diabetes are euthanized within a year of diagnosis due to various factors, including lack of awareness and understanding of the condition.

  1. Glucose is the body's main energy source, regulated by insulin, a hormone produced by the pancreas.
  2. In diabetic animals, low insulin levels cause high blood sugar. Middle-aged, obese, and unspayed female dogs are at higher risk.
  3. There are two types of diabetes in pets: Type 1, which is common in dogs but rare in cats, and Type 2, which is the opposite.
  4. Symptoms of diabetes in pets develop gradually but can worsen quickly if untreated. Key signs include increased thirst, urination, appetite, and weight loss.
  5. Cats may develop a flat-footed stance, while dogs are prone to cataracts.
  6. Management of diabetes in pets involves SGLT2 inhibitors for early stages and long-acting insulin injections for advanced cases, along with gradual weight loss and low-carb diets for cats.
  7. Insulin therapy remains the cornerstone of treatment, despite the rarity of diabetes reversal in dogs.
"Sadly, around 20% of pets with diabetes are euthanized within a year of diagnosis."

Understanding and managing diabetes in pets is crucial for their well-being and longevity. Regular vet check-ups and proper diet management can significantly improve the quality of life for diabetic pets.

item.title: Each cigarette smoked steals 20 mins of life expectancy: UCL study - Business Standard
item.description:
Each Cigarette Smoked Steals 20 Minutes of Life Expectancy, Reveals UCL Study

Date: October 2023 | Source: University College London

A new research from University College London indicates that each cigarette smoked reduces life expectancy by an average of 20 minutes. The study also found that quitting smoking can significantly recover lost life.

  • Every pack of 20 cigarettes smoked correlates with a loss of nearly seven hours of life.
  • Quitting smoking on New Year’s Day can reclaim an entire day of life by January 8.
  • By mid-February, individuals could recover one full week; by year-end, up to 50 days.
  • The UK government is implementing measures to phase out the sale of tobacco to individuals born after January 1, 2009.
  • A survey indicates that 53% of smokers plan to quit as part of their 2025 New Year resolutions.
  • Smoking is responsible for around 80,000 deaths annually in the UK.
“Stopping smoking is one of the best things you can do to improve your current and future health.” - Jeanelle de Gruchy, England’s Deputy Chief Medical Officer

Quitting smoking greatly improves health almost immediately, with benefits such as easier breathing and increased energy levels observed within 72 hours.

item.title: Advantage Healthcare & Physiotherapy Expands Women’s Physiotherapy Services - GlobeNewswire
item.description:
Advantage Healthcare & Physiotherapy Expands Women’s Physiotherapy Services

Date: Dec. 30, 2024 | Source: GLOBE NEWSWIRE

Many women have suffered in silence regarding pelvic health issues, but increased awareness is leading to better access to specialized physiotherapy services targeted at these conditions.

  • The clinic is expanding its team of women’s health physiotherapists to meet growing demand.
  • Specialists offer treatments for conditions including pelvic floor issues, pelvic pain, endometriosis, and urinary incontinence.
  • Pelvic floor exercises are an effective treatment for urinary incontinence, often recommended before more invasive procedures.
  • Additionally, the clinic offers pediatric physiotherapy to assist children with developmental challenges.
“Helping children with disabilities is a fulfilling job,” said Jenny. “Helping make a difference in their lives and seeing the joy on their faces when they achieve what they previously couldn’t is amazing.”

This expansion of services demonstrates a commitment to enhancing women's health and wellness in the community, addressing often overlooked issues.

item.title: IIT Bombay researchers develop needle-free ‘shock’ syringe - News9 LIVE
item.description:
IIT Bombay researchers develop needle-free ‘shock’ syringe

New Delhi: Researchers from IIT Bombay have developed a ‘shock’ syringe that delivers medication using shock waves, eliminating the need for needles.

The device uses a micro shock tube to create a rapid jet stream of liquid that penetrates the skin, allowing for painless drug delivery.

  • The shock syringe is longer than a regular ballpoint pen and uses pressurized nitrogen to deliver medication.
  • Tests on lab rats showed results comparable to conventional syringes.
  • Could facilitate quicker vaccination drives and alleviate fears associated with needles, especially for children.
  • Less skin damage compared to traditional needle injections, reducing trauma from injections.
“The shock syringe is designed to deliver the medication rapidly,” - Priyanka Hankare, lead author of the research paper.

This innovation highlights the potential to transform drug delivery methods, pending further research and regulatory approval.

item.title: Accuracy of ESAT6-CFP10 skin test compared with tuberculin skin test in a healthy population: a randomized, blind, parallel controlled phase III clinical study - BMC Infectious Diseases
item.description:
EC Skin Test Accuracy and Booster Effect Factors

This randomized, double-blind, parallel-controlled phase III clinical trial evaluated the accuracy of the ESAT6-CFP10 (EC) skin test compared to the tuberculin skin test (TB-PPD) and interferon-gamma release assay (T-SPOT) in a healthy population. The trial also determined factors influencing the booster effect of EC.

  • The trial was conducted at the Jiangsu Center for Disease Control and Prevention in China.
  • Healthy participants aged 18-65 were enrolled and provided written informed consent.
  • The experiment was divided into two stages, with the first stage involving all participants undergoing T-SPOT, TB-PPD, and EC tests. In the second stage, tri-negative participants (negative in all three tests) were randomly assigned to receive BCG or placebo vaccinations and underwent the tests again after 12 weeks.
  • The primary endpoints were reactions at the injection sites and safety results within 48 hours after the skin tests, while the secondary endpoints were booster effects of skin tests.
  • In the first stage, 1,564 participants were enrolled, and in the second stage, 585 tri-negative participants were randomly assigned to the BCG or placebo groups.
  • The positivity rates and concordance of the three tests were calculated in both stages, and a logistic regression model was used to determine factors influencing the EC booster effect.
  • Safety observations continued until the skin test results were available.

Results

  • The positivity rates of the T-SPOT, EC, and TB-PPD tests in the first stage were 18.89%, 10.37%, and 53.96%, respectively. The concordance between the EC and T-SPOT tests was 88.97% (kappa = 0.56), and that between the TB-PPD and T-SPOT tests was 58.19% (kappa = 0.20).
  • In the second stage, the overall positivity rates of the T-SPOT, EC, and TB-PPD tests in the tri-negative participants were 5.47%, 8.84%, and 62.11%, respectively. The concordance between the EC and T-SPOT tests was 93.68% (kappa = 0.53), and that between the TB-PPD and T-SPOT tests was 43.37% (kappa = 0.06).
  • The factors associated with the EC booster effect were age ≥ 60 years and retest positivity of the T-SPOT test.
  • Adverse events occurred in 328 (20.97%) participants in the first stage, with most being local adverse reactions.

Discussion

The EC skin test showed similar diagnostic performance to the T-SPOT test in the healthy population and was unaffected by BCG vaccination. The booster effects were more likely to occur in populations with retest positivity of the T-SPOT test or age ≥ 60 years.

Source: BMC Infectious Diseases, Volume 24, Article number: 1479, 2024

item.title: Drinking coffee every day could have a big impact on your body, according to a new study - Marca.com
item.description:
Daily Coffee Consumption Linked to Major Health Benefits

Published on Dec 30, 2024 in Marca

Consuming a cup of coffee daily can have significant health impacts, according to a new study.

  1. Cardiovascular benefits: Moderate coffee consumption reduces the risk of cardiovascular disease due to antioxidants like polyphenols that improve heart health and blood flow.
  2. Cognitive performance improvement: Coffee's caffeine can enhance alertness, concentration, and lower the risk of cognitive decline with age.
  3. Reducing chronic diseases risk: Daily coffee consumption is linked to a lower risk of type 2 diabetes and certain cancers due to its anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties.

item.title: Want To Lose Weight In 2025? These 5 New Year Resolutions Can Fix Your Diet And Nutrition - ABP Live
item.description:
Want To Lose Weight In 2025? These 5 New Year Resolutions Can Fix Your Diet And Nutrition

Date: 2023

Source: ABP Live

This article provides a roadmap for achieving weight loss goals in 2025 by focusing on healthy eating habits and lifestyle changes.

  • 1. Eat Real Food: Choose food closer to nature to improve nutrition absorption.
  • 2. Practise Mindfulness: Eat in a calm state to aid digestion and nutrient absorption.
  • 3. Move a lot: Engage in frequent physical activity to enhance health.
  • 4. Use relaxation techniques: Manage daily stress through activities you enjoy.
  • 5. Don't be scared of food: Avoid fad diets and focus on overall health for weight management.
"Food is Sadhna. Earn it well," says Deepta Nagpal.

In conclusion, adopting these resolutions can lead to a healthier lifestyle and successful weight loss in the new year.

item.title: Burnt your mouth? 5 home remedies to heal faster - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Home Remedies to Soothe a Burnt Mouth

Published: December 29, 2024 | Source: Hindustan Times

Burnt your mouth on hot food or drinks? Here are some quick and effective home remedies to heal your mouth burn and reduce pain.

  1. Cold water or ice cubes: Rinse your mouth with cold water or suck on ice cubes to reduce swelling and numb the pain immediately.
  2. Dairy relief with yogurt or milk: Milk or yogurt cools the burning sensation and creates a protective layer to soothe irritation.
  3. Honey's healing power: Honey, with its anti-inflammatory properties, helps reduce pain, prevent infection, and promotes faster healing.
  4. Aloe vera gel for quick relief: Aloe vera’s cooling properties reduce inflammation and speed up healing when applied directly to the burn.
  5. Saltwater rinse: A simple saltwater rinse cleanses the area and reduces the risk of infection. Rinse several times a day.

Try these home remedies to find quick relief and speed up the healing process.

item.title: Scientists in Guwahati make breakthrough, fabricate Lysozyme bilayers at room temperature - ThePrint
item.description:
Scientists in Guwahati make breakthrough, fabricate Lysozyme bilayers at room temperature

Date: Not specified
Source: PIB press release

This research by scientists from the IASST in Guwahati demonstrates the fabrication of lysozyme bilayers at room temperature, mimicking natural protein adsorption processes.

  • Researchers fabricated lysozyme bilayers on silicon surfaces at room temperature.
  • This breakthrough offers insights into ion-mediated protein interactions relevant to implants and biomaterials.
  • Lysozyme, found in various bodily fluids, is central to this study.
  • The research explains the stabilization mechanisms of lysozyme bilayers through various interactions.
  • The findings could enhance understanding of biological protein adsorption on medical devices.
“This research holds great significance for mimicking biological protein adsorption processes on implanted devices and biomaterials.”

This study represents a significant advancement in biomaterial science, suggesting potential for improved outcomes in implant technologies.

item.title: Norovirus cases surge in US: What you need to know about the stomach flu? Explained in 10 points - The Economic Times
item.description:
Norovirus cases surge in US: What you need to know about the stomach flu?

Publication Date: December 2023
Source: Economic Times

Norovirus cases are surging in parts of the United States this winter, with the CDC reporting double the cases compared to previous years, particularly in early December.

The article highlights several key points regarding the outbreak of Norovirus:

  • Norovirus, known as the stomach flu, is highly contagious and can cause severe vomiting and diarrhea.
  • The CDC reported 91 cases during the week of December 5, 2023, which is twice the highest recorded number between 2021 and 2024.
  • It is responsible for 58% of foodborne illnesses in the US and can easily spread in communal settings.
  • Vulnerable populations include children under five and seniors over 85.
  • Common symptoms include nausea, stomach pain, and weakness; onset typically occurs within 12 to 48 hours after exposure.
  • Prevention measures include thorough handwashing, staying home when infected, and cleaning contaminated surfaces.
"Norovirus illness typically causes a range of symptoms that appear suddenly."

In conclusion, with the recent surge in Norovirus cases, it is crucial to remain informed about symptoms, prevention, and treatment to manage and mitigate the outbreak effectively.

item.title: Norovirus cases surge in US: What you need to know about the stomach flu? 10 points - The Economic Times
